stem: What’s the correct way to leak‑test oxy‑fuel connections?

choices.text: Use an open flame — it’s faster
Listen for hissing — that’s enough
Apply a soapy solution/leak detector and watch for bubbles
Submerge the torch in water

rationales.CHOICE-3: A soapy solution safely shows micro‑bubbling; open‑flame checks or ‘listening only’ are unacceptable.

stem: Lighting sequence for a hand torch:

choices.text: Open oxygen, ignite, then add acetylene
Open both gases fully and ignite
Crack acetylene at the torch, ignite, then add oxygen to a neutral flame
Ignite the work first, then bring in the torch

rationales.CHOICE-3: Start with a small fuel flow, then add oxygen to set a neutral flame.

stem: A safe full shutdown after work includes:

choices.text: Close only the torch valves — leave regulators alone
Close cylinder valves, bleed lines through the torch, back out regulator screws to zero
Leave pressure in hoses — faster next day
Vent through the regulator, keep cylinders open

rationales.CHOICE-2: Shut cylinders, depressurize lines, and release regulator spring load to reduce risk and wear.

stem: Proper cylinder position for use/storage:

choices.text: Laid horizontally — more stable
Upright and securely restrained (chain/strap)
On a hand truck at an angle, unrestrained
Any position if the cap is on

rationales.CHOICE-2: Keep cylinders vertical and secured to prevent tipping and acetone carryover (acetylene).

stem: Acetylene 1/7 rule: from a T cylinder (~300 ft³) you may withdraw no more than…

choices.text: ≈25 CFH
≈43 CFH
≈70 CFH
≈100 CFH

rationales.CHOICE-2: 1/7 of 300 ft³ ≈ 42.9 CFH; higher rates pull acetone and destabilize the flame.

stem: Convert 50 CFH to L/min:

choices.text: ≈8 L/min
≈12 L/min
≈24 L/min
≈80 L/min

stem: A rosebud needs 25 L/min of acetylene. How many CFH is that?

choices.text: ≈18 CFH
≈53 CFH
≈75 CFH
≈125 CFH

stem: Your rosebud needs 80 CFH acetylene and you have a single T cylinder. What’s the safe option?

choices.text: Open acetylene fully — the regulator will hold it
Lower oxygen pressure and carry on
Use a cylinder manifold or switch to an alternative fuel
Periodically flip the cylinder to ‘add liquid’

rationales.CHOICE-3: 80 CFH exceeds the 1/7 rule for one cylinder; solution: manifold cylinders or another fuel.

stem: Where are reverse‑flow checks and flashback arrestors installed?

choices.text: Oxygen side only, at the regulator
Check valves at the torch; flashback arrestors on both gas lines at the regulator and/or torch
Fuel side only, at the torch
Not needed with a neutral flame

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use check valves and arrestors on both lines to prevent reverse flow and stop flame propagation.

stem: Difference between a check valve and a flashback arrestor:

choices.text: No difference — same device
Check valve prevents reverse gas flow; arrestor stops a flame front
An arrestor just filters dust
A check valve extinguishes flames; an arrestor doesn’t

rationales.CHOICE-2: Different functions: reverse‑flow prevention vs flame stopping.

stem: Signs of a flashback (squeal, body heating). First actions:

choices.text: Continue until it stops on its own
Shut torch valves immediately, close cylinders, let it cool, inspect arrestors/tip
Add oxygen to cool it
Dip the torch in water and continue

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stop gas flow fast, cool down, and inspect to minimize damage and hose fire risk.

stem: When and how should hoses be purged after installing regulators?

choices.text: Never — visual inspection is enough
Open each gas at the torch briefly and separately in a ventilated area away from ignition sources
Open both gases together — faster purge
Purge through the tip with the flame lit

rationales.CHOICE-2: Brief separate purges remove air/moisture without mixing gases.

stem: How far do you open an acetylene cylinder valve in use?

choices.text: Fully backseat
About 1/2–3/4 turn (not more than one turn)
2–3 full turns
Only 1/8 turn — more is unsafe

rationales.CHOICE-2: A small opening allows quick shutoff in an emergency.

stem: How should you open an oxygen cylinder valve?

choices.text: Quickly to half a turn — that’s enough
Slowly and fully (backseat)
Don’t open — the regulator will pull it open
Snap it fully open

rationales.CHOICE-2: Open slowly and fully for proper valve function and stable flow.

stem: What to do with regulator adjusting screws at full shutdown?

choices.text: Leave them at working pressure to keep settings
Back them out to zero to remove spring/diaphragm load
Tighten fully to prevent vibration
It doesn’t matter

rationales.CHOICE-2: Releasing the screw prevents spring ‘set’ and extends regulator life.

stem: Why shouldn’t high‑purity copper parts/tubing be used with acetylene?

choices.text: Copper quickly corrodes in oxygen
Explosive copper acetylide can form
It reduces joint thermal conductivity
It’s just a recommendation, not a hazard

rationales.CHOICE-2: Some non‑ferrous metals form unstable acetylides with acetylene — impact‑sensitive and hazardous.

stem: Safe way to move gas cylinders in the shop:

choices.text: Roll them on the floor horizontally
Lift with a magnetic crane by the shell
Use a proper cart with a chain and the cap on
‘Walk’ them on the edge while bracing with your foot

rationales.CHOICE-3: Use a cart/chain and a protective cap — prevents tipping and valve impact.

stem: Before cutting a closed vessel/confined space you should:

choices.text: Fill with oxygen to burn off vapors
Crack a lid slightly and cut
Clean/ventilate, perform gas testing, and obtain a hot‑work permit
Pour in some water — that’s enough

rationales.CHOICE-3: Confined‑space cutting requires prep: remove vapors, verify atmosphere, and get authorization.

stem: Most likely cause of a backfire during cutting:

choices.text: Hoses are too clean
Tip touches metal/slag or passages are clogged
Excess ventilation in the area
Any torch tilt over 5°

rationales.CHOICE-2: Contact and clogging cause local overheating/reverse wave — a typical backfire cause.

stem: Use PTFE (Teflon) tape on the regulator‑to‑cylinder connection?

choices.text: Yes, always — improves sealing
No; CGA connections seal metal‑to‑metal/with a gasket — tape isn’t used
Only on oxygen — it’s drier
Only if there’s a leak — wrap more

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cylinder‑to‑regulator joints seal on the seating surfaces; tape is for specified pipe threads further downstream.

stem: Typical torch orientation for straight cutting on thick plate:

choices.text: Perfectly vertical to the surface
A small 10–20° lead angle in the direction of travel
At 45° away from you to blow slag off
Nozzle pointing backward — easier to hold

rationales.CHOICE-2: A slight lead angle improves slag removal and stream stability on thick sections.

stem: What is the maximum recommended working pressure for acetylene?

choices.text: Safe above 30 psi (≈207 kPa)
Do not use acetylene above 15 psi (≈103 kPa)
Any pressure is acceptable if flashback arrestors are installed
Always 5 psi or less

rationales.CHOICE-2: Acetylene becomes unstable at about 15 psi; working pressure is kept below this level.

stem: Why briefly crack a cylinder valve before attaching the regulator?

choices.text: To vent gas for no reason
To blow dust/debris off the outlet seat
To cool the valve
To test the regulator threads

rationales.CHOICE-2: A short crack removes contaminants that could damage the regulator.

stem: Which description matches a neutral oxy‑fuel flame?

choices.text: A long carburizing acetylene feather
A balanced inner cone with no feather
An oxidizing feather on the inner cone
A loud popping flame

rationales.CHOICE-2: A neutral flame has a distinct inner cone without an acetylene feather.

stem: Which statement about oxy‑fuel hose/fitting threads is correct?

choices.text: Fuel‑gas fittings use right‑hand threads
Fuel‑gas fittings use left‑hand threads (often notched); oxygen uses right‑hand threads
Oxygen uses left‑hand threads
Both use tapered pipe threads

rationales.CHOICE-2: Left‑hand threads on fuel lines help prevent cross‑connection with oxygen.

stem: How should oxygen equipment be handled?

choices.text: Use oil/grease to stop leaks
Never use oil/grease on oxygen equipment
Always fully backseat the acetylene valve
Do not crack the valve before installing the regulator

rationales.CHOICE-2: Oil and grease can ignite in pure oxygen service.

stem: Which plate‑piercing technique for oxy‑fuel cutting is correct?

choices.text: Lay the tip flat and immediately open full oxygen jet
Tilt the tip, preheat, then open the oxygen jet to pierce
Always start only from an edge
Hold the tip strictly vertical with no preheat

rationales.CHOICE-2: Preheating with a slight tilt reduces blowback of slag and tip damage risk.

stem: Insufficient preheat during cutting often leads to:

choices.text: Smooth, slag‑free cuts
Excess slag and a ‘hard’ start
A narrow kerf and perfect straightness
No change

rationales.CHOICE-2: Too little preheat impairs ignition and jet formation, increasing slag.

stem: Why clean cutting tips with proper cleaners/gauges?

choices.text: To enlarge the orifices for higher flow
To maintain correct orifice size/shape and cut quality
To reduce preheat
To strip off plating

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct cleaners preserve orifice geometry for a stable flame pattern.

stem: How do you correctly distinguish a backfire from a flashback?

choices.text: Backfire is when the flame runs into the hoses
Flashback is sustained burning into the torch/hose; backfire is a brief ‘pop’ at the tip
There is no difference
Backfire is preferable and safer

rationales.CHOICE-2: A backfire is a short pop at the tip; a flashback is sustained internal burning and a serious hazard.

stem: If travel speed during cutting is too high, the cut will be:

choices.text: With heavy bottom slag
With lag lines leaning far backward (drag)
Unchanged and perfectly straight
With a surface‑hardened steel face

rationales.CHOICE-2: Excessive speed increases jet lag; too slow tends to produce heavy bottom slag.
